questions.text: Respiratory quotient of a patient exclusively on carbohydrate diet?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1

RQ (Respiratory quotient) is defined as ratio of CO2 produced and O2 consumed after combustion of 1 gram of any particular food item. RQ of various food items are

Carbohydrate: 1

Protein: 0.84

Fat: 0.71

questions.text: Action of Thyroid hormones T3 and T4 on thyroid hormone receptors is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

It acts as Transcription factor

Thyroid hormone and retinoic acid directly enter the nucleus where they bind TR-RXR heterodimer. Binding of these hormone to these receptor dissociates the transcription corepressor complex. This results is gene transcription.

questions.text: Fastest way to re-generate ATP during exercise
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Creatine phosphate

During exercise existing ATP in the skeletal  muscle last only for 2 seconds. In case of continued exercise rapid re synthesis of muscle ATP is required for which phosphocreatinine is cleaved rapidally to resynthesize the ATP. Role of glycolysis to provide the ATP comes only next followed by TCA cycle.

[Ref. Harper’s   Illustrated   Biochemistry      28thed,   chapter    11. Pg95 ]

[Voet  and   Voet   Biochemistry     chapter    27   pg    1092]

questions.text: Vitamin toxicity causing teratogenicity is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A         

•    Vitamin A has been found to have teratogenic  role.

•    Retinoids, the synthetic derivates of vitamin A, have a key role on cellular differentiation and developmental tissue specificity.

•    Their effects are mediated by nuclear receptors which transactivate homeobox genes.

•    They are teratogenic to animals and they all induce similar malformations dependent on the dose and the duration of exposure

questions.text: Pathway describes synthesis of metabolically active Vitamin D?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Skin – Liver – Kidney

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  

•    Produced in skin, cholecalciferol goes to liver where it is hydroxylated to produce 25 hydroxy-cholecalciferol which then enters the PCT  where is converted to 1,25 hydroxy cholecalciferol

•    1,25 hydroxy cholecalciferol is the most active form of vitamin D

questions.text: If consecutive nucleotides code for an amino acid, how many amino acid can be theoretically coded by nucleic acid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

256

  • If there would have been two nucleotide in each codon the chance of their varied combination will be 42 i.e. 16, and three nucleotide in each codon means there will occur 43 i.e. 64 codons are possible.
  • According to the above calculation, if there occurs 4 nucleotide in a codon, the chance of there varied combination will be 44 i.e. 256.

So the answer of above question will be (D) 256

questions.text: A person ingests 100 gms of proteins/day and excretes 25 gms of nitrogen. What is he/she?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Clinically ill

Nitrogen Balance

  • Nitrogen balance can be actually measured by calculating the dietary intake of protein nitrogen (16% of the weight of the ingested proteins) and comparing it with the daily nitrogen excretion.
  • A normal healthy adult is said to be in nitrogen balance if the dietary intake of nitrogen (I) = daily loss in urine (U) + Feces (F) + skin (S).
  • I = U + F + S
  • In the above question, the person ingests 100 gms (which amounts in 16 gms of ingested nitrogen) of proteins/day and excretes 25 grams of nitrogen/day.
  • Hence the rate of nitrogen excretion is more than that of ingestion. Hence the person is in a state of negative nitrogen balance which is common in ILLNESS

questions.text: DNA microarrays allow detection of gene mutations using?
questions.solution:

Hybridization

DNA microarray is based on the principle of DNA hybridization. It can be used to find out expression of gene and also can be used for mutation analysis.

questions.text: Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin) act by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase. What is the function of DNA gyrase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Relieve torsional strain on DNA

TOPOISOMERASE

✓  Relieves the torsional strain produced by unwinding of DNA

•    The enzyme causes nicks in the DNA by transesterification and not by hydrolysis of phosphodiester bond

•    Topoisomerase I:

-Makes single stranded nicks in the DNA

- Relieves positive and negative supercoils in eukaryotes

- Requires no ATP

•    Topoisomerase II:

-Relives positive and negative supercoiling

-Can introduce negative supercoiling

-Requires ATP

-DNA gyrase is a subset of Topoisomerase II.

questions.text: True statement regarding chaperone proteins is the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Show ATPase activity

Explanation: Chaperone proteins

•    Present in prokaryotes as well as eukaryotes

•    Induced by heat, stress or acidosis

•    Bind to hydrophobic regions of unfolded and aggregated proteins and act as a quality control or editing mechanism for detecting misfolded proteins

•    Most show ATPase activity

•    Found in cytosol, mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum lumen

•    Examples include Heat shock proteins, Calnexin, calreticulin, BiP, GRP94, PDI, PPI etc

questions.text: One of the first chemotherapeutic agents was methotrexate , a compound that was effective in killing rapidly dividing cells like those of leukemias. This compound would be expected to elevate concentrations of Which of the following compounds?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Homocysteine and dUMP

  • This enzyme is needed for conversion of homocystein to the methionine
  • This is B12 dependent enzyme, which requires methyl THF as a methyl donor. Deficiency of vitamin B12 leads to accumulation of methyl THF (Folate trap).
  • As free form of THF is required for the synthesis of N5 – N10 methylene THF, a form of THF required for the synthesis of dTMP from dUMP by the enzyme thymidylate synthetase, the deficiency of B12 leads to defective synthesis of the dTMP and thus that of the DNA and thus megaloblatic anemia.

questions.text: A 2-year old child is hospitalized for evaluation of poor growth and low muscle tone. The most striking physical findings is unruly, “Kinky’’ hair but the child also has increased joint laxity and thin skin. Which of following lab findings is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In Menke disease the affected child has got excess content of copper in the GIT mucosa. This is because of mutation in the transport protein Cu binding ATPase 7A, the protein which is needed to transport the copper from GIT mucosa to the capillaries.

questions.text: Which if the following is an example of reverse transcriptase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Telomerase

•    Reverse transcriptase is a RNA dependant DNA polymerase.

•    Telomerase is a reverse transcriptase present in human germline cells (spermatogonia, oogonia) and stem cells (in skin, bone marrow and gut) but is absent from most other somatic cells.

•    When a somatic cell without telomerase divides the telomere length increases by 50-100 by per cell division. Most somatic cells in culture reach a point of senescence where they stop dividing.

•    However some somatic cells that are deficient in tumor suppressor genes (p53 and Rb) can continue beyond senescence and hit a crisis point where most cells die but a few cells survive thatave gross chromosomal )

questions.text: Which of the following represents the most characteristic function of Type II Restriction Enzymes:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cut DNA at palindromic sites

Restriction enzymes are specific enzymes which identify palindromic sequence.

Palindromes are local symmetrical areas where double strand DNA have same sequence on either strand in a particular direction.

questions.text: In the synthesis of collagen, the hydroxylation of proline and lysine occurs in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•    Prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase are the two enzymes that carry out hydroxylation of proline and lysine.

•    The process is both co- and posttranslational and, therefore, occurs during, or more often after, the amino acids are inserted into nascent collagen polypeptide chains in the RER.

•    Hydroxyproline, which constitutes 10% of collagen, is often used to determine the collagen content of various tissues.

•    Hydroxylation of proline stabilizes the triple helix through interchain hydrogen bonds, and hydroxylation of lysine is critical for the cross-linking stage of collagen assembly.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is true ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

N-linked glycosylation occurs in the ER

Ref:Read the text below

Sol:

•    After the correct addition of the first 8 to 20 amino acids, a special signal is encountered in most of the proteins that are destined for secretion, lysosomes, or the plasma membrane.

•    This signal peptide causes the ribosome to stop translating the transcript and move to the ER. ER with aggregations of ribosomes is often called the rough ER because of its dense, speckled appearance.

•    Proteins that are ultimately destined for the cytoplasm (e.g., hexokinase) do not have a special signal, and their translation is finished on free ribosomes void of any ER interaction.

•    Proteins are typically translocated across the ER membrane into the lumen cotranslationally. N-linked glycosylation occurs in the ER. The ER plays a major role not only in protein synthesis but also in lipid biosynthesis.

•    It may also function to sequester calcium from the cytoplasm by actively pumping calcium into the ER lumen (e.g., sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle).

questions.text: True statement(s) regarding Telomerase is/are?
questions.solution:

Works as reverse transcriptase

Telomerase is a reverse transcriptase which produces DNA complimentary to RNA. Synthesis is in 5-3 direction.

choices.text: Adjusting  pH   to  other  than  the  isoelectic point

questions.text: Precipitation of  proteins    is  done  by  all  these  except  :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Adjusting  pH   to  other  than  the  isoelectic point   

Ref: Harper:  illustrated   Biochemistry   30/e p26

At isoelectric pH(pI)  protein is neutral and hence insoluble. On adjusting the pH on either side of pI, it gets charged and becomes soluble.

questions.text: CG  rich   islands    in  DNA    is  used  for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Methylation   

•    Epigenetic changes are non-mutational changes where gene expression is regulated.

•    Methylation of bases in the DNA is one of the epigenetic change, the other type of epigenetic change is covalent modification of histone proteins.

•    Cytosine is the usual base [in CpG island] of the  DNA which undergoes methylation. This epigenetic change is seen to be associated with suppression of certain genes.

•    Histone undergo following covalent modification: Ubiquitinylation, phosphorylation,methylation and acetylation

Ref.  Harper’s   illustrated   biochemistry 30th  Ed, Pg 735

questions.text: Mitochondrial codons are an exception for the property of “universality” of codons. For eg: Initiation codon in mammals is AUG, which codes for methionine. But in mitochondria, methionine is coded by some other codon. Which among the following is that initiation codon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

AUA        
   
•    Each codon consists of a sequence of 3 nucleotides

•    In mammalian cells, AUG codes for methionine (initiation colon)

•    Stop codons are: UGA, UAG and UAA.

✓  In mitochondria:

-    AUA codes for methionine (mitochondrial initiation codon)

-    UGA codes for tryptophan

-    AGA and AGG serve as chain terminators

►  In prokaryotes, AUG, the initiation codon codes for Formyl methionine

►  Features of Genetic code:

I.    Degenerate: There are 61 codons for 20 amino acids

I.    This implies multiple codons decode the same amino acid

II.    Unambiguous: Given a specific codon, only a single amino acid is indicated

III.    Non-overlapping

IV.    No punctuation

V.    Universal

questions.text: Which one of the following enzymes uses molecular oxygen as a hydrogen acceptor?

Cytochrome c oxidase

Oxidases are enzymes which tend to donate the reducing equivalent to molecular oxygen. Oxidases belong to class I enzyme Oxidoreductase.

questions.text: Given that DNA polymerases are unable to synthesize DNA without a primer, what molecule serves as the primer for these enzymes during DNA replication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A short RNA molecule

questions.text: In analyzing a sample of double-stranded DNA, it has been determined that the molar ratio of adenosine is 20%. Given this information, what is the content of cytidine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

30

Ref– Read the text below

Sol:

•    The molar ratio of adenosine in any molecule of double-stranded DNA will be equivalent to that of thymidine, since these two nucleotides hydrogen bond to form base pairs.

•    Therefore, the total amount of the DNA accounted for in A-T base pairs would be 40%.

•    Since guanosine and cytidine hydrogen bond to form base pairs, they too contribute an equivalent molar ratio in double-stranded DNA. In double-stranded DNA with 40% A-T  composition, the molar ratio of cytidine would be half of the remaining 60% of the DNA, or 30%.

questions.text: The predominant isoenzyme of LDH in the cardiac muscle is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

LDH – 1

  • In myocardial infarction level of LDH – 1 increases and this leads to altered ratio of LDH.
  • It means LDH – 1 > LDH – 2.
  • This altered ratio of the LDH is known as flipped pattern.

Bind to Fe+++ of cytochrome a3

Respiration and energy production is the coupled process, so inhibition of one inhibits the other as well.

HDL is the lipoprotein which moves farthest from starting point on electrophoresis

questions.text: All are true about HDL except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pre beta HDL is the inactive precursor, which later forms the active HDL

HDL

•    HDL scavenges body cholesterol & blood vessel wall cholesterol to liver. This transport of tissue cholesterol to liver is known as reverse cholesterol transport.

•    Class B scavenger receptor B1 (SR-B1) and ATO binding cassette transporter A1 (ABCA1) and G1 (ABCG1) are involved in reverse cholesterol transport

•    ABCA1 mediates efflux of cholesterol from peripheral cells

•    SRB1 mediates uptake of cholesterol from peripheral cells

•    HDL contains good cholesterol

•    Pre β-HDL is the most potent form of HDL for cholesterol removal from tissues

•    HDL is synthesized in liver and intestine
